John Russell Brown, who has died aged 91, was a distinguished Shakespearean scholar who was also involved in practical theatre – he was a close associate of the director Peter Hall at the National Theatre for 15 years from 1973 – but was paradoxically opposed to directors filtering the plays though their own ideas, concepts and interpretations.

In one of his many books, Free Shakespeare (1974), he advocated the primacy of Shakespeare’s musical language in contemporary production, the aspiration of an Elizabethan style of spontaneity in performance and unostentatious decor. He seemed not to see the irony in adopting so idealistic and conceptual an approach himself; his advocacy turned Hall into a reformed classicist and led to austere and unexciting NT productions of Hamlet and Macbeth, both starring Albert Finney, in 1976 and 1978.

At least he was consistent, seeing no division at all between his response to Shakespeare when he read the plays, taught them in a classroom, saw them in performance, or worked on them in the theatre. As well as his books on Shakespeare’s comedies, tragedies and dramatic style, he prepared new editions of The Merchant of Venice and of John Webster’s two masterpieces, The Duchess of Malfi and The White Devil, and directed productions of the plays in Britain, New Zealand and the US.

In his field, he was regarded as a pioneer; he took forward the work of Allardyce Nicoll, who in 1951 founded the Shakespeare Institute in Stratford-upon-Avon with a view to working closely with Barry Jackson, who was then running the Shakespeare Festival in the Memorial Theatre in Stratford. This relationship between the academic world and the Royal Shakespeare Company – exemplified in the career of Russell Brown’s friend and successor, Stanley Wells, who became a governor and vice-chairman of the RSC – has varied in intensity but is undergoing a renewal in Gregory Doran’s artistic directorship. The Nicoll revolution was to consider Shakespeare not just as text, but as text in performance.

Russell Brown’s scholarly articles in publications such as Shakespeare Survey, Critical Quarterly and the Tulane Drama Review were always worth reading. His 1957 book Shakespeare and His Comedies was one of the first to take the comedies seriously, and his more recent editions Directors’ Shakespeare (2008) and Actors’ Shakespeare (2011) – with essays by Wells on Judi Dench and Paul Edmondson on Harriet Walter – are essential documents of the contemporary theatre.

He edited the Oxford Illustrated History of the Theatre (2001), one of the outstanding books of its kind, with definitive essays by Martin Esslin (on modern theatre 1890-1920), Peter Holland (18th century), Oliver Taplin (Greek theatre) and Peter Thomson (English Renaissance and Restoration drama), Russell Brown himself providing a magisterial, international overview of theatre since 1970. Unlike many Shakespearean scholars, he kept up to date, supporting Hall in his championing of Edward Bond, Howard Brenton and David Hare at the National, and he remained well informed on developments across Europe and in America and Japan.

He was the second son of Russell Alan Brown, a first world war veteran and pork butcher, and his wife, Olive (nee Golding), a teacher. The family lived above the shop in Gloucester Road, Bristol, and the boys, David and John, were educated at Monkton Combe school, near Bath. David was destined for the church – he became, eventually, bishop of Guildford. John left school aged 15 and joined the family business but caught the theatre bug at seaside pier shows. When the second world war broke out in 1939, he joined the Fleet Air Arm and was transferred to Scotland, where he serviced Spitfires and luckily avoided a posting on a ship that sank with all hands on board.

After the war, he found his way to Keble College, Oxford, where he read English and tutored undergraduates in Anglo-Saxon, supervised by JRR Tolkien. His academic career started at the Shakespeare Institute, where he was a fellow (1951-55), followed by 10 years as an English lecturer at Birmingham University, becoming professor and head of drama and theatre arts at Birmingham from 1964 to 1971. Ever active, ever busy, he was professor of English at Sussex University (1971-82) during his time with Hall. When Richard Eyre succeeded Hall at the NT and appointed Nicholas Wright as his literary manager, Russell Brown concentrated on his writing and was professor of theatre at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor (1985-97).

For Hall, he regarded himself as “a resident researcher and critic in search of plays that surprise me”, and he directed one or two of them himself, including Alegrio Alonso’s Crossing Niagara at the ICA in 1975, Peter Handke’s They Are Dying Out at the Young Vic in 1976 and Barry Collins’s Judgement in the NT’s Cottesloe in 1977, the last of these a searing monodrama for a cannibalistic Russian army officer, played by Ben Kingsley.

Tall, affable, industrious and encouraging – and a keen gardener – Russell Brown represented the best of the scholar/practitioner/teacher tradition he helped establish in British theatre.

He is survived by his wife, Hilary (nee Baker), whom he married in 1961 when she was a student of his at Birmingham, their three children, Jasper, Alice and Sophie, and nine grandchildren.
